article_title: Hospitals with high readmission rates face penalties

article_metadata.description: The great-grandmother with a disarming smile and a pink scar from open-heart surgery peeking from the neck of her dress has congestive heart failure.  Plagued with heart problems since childhood, her condition worsened last fall when she was having trouble breathing and was admitted to Memorial Hermann Sugar Land Hospital for several days.  The federal government estimates nearly one in five Medicare patients return to the hospital within 30 days of discharge, resulting in 2 million readmissions each year.  Not only is the price tag to Medicare staggering - an estimated $26 billion per year - but if a patient returns too soon and too often, it raises questions about her or his original care.  Even more concerning, the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services estimates as much as $17 billion of those readmission costs are potentially avoidable.  [...] it was just the opposite.  A 1 percent difference in Medicare revenues can mean the difference between making a profit and ending up in the red, says Vivian Ho, the James A. Baker III Institute Chair in Health Economics at Rice University.  Hospitals exempt from the penalties include some small rural hospitals, children's and veteran's hospitals, as well as specialty hospitals such as some cancer facilities, rehabilitation or psychiatric hospitals.  Penalties are higher this year in most hospitals because two new patient categories were added: elective knee and hip replacement and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.  Hospitals were never held responsible for patients after they went home, says Dr. Robert Phillips, executive vice president and chief medical officer at Houston Methodist.  [...] while most agree that things are moving in the right direction, some criticize the one-size-fits-all penalty assessment that does not take into account differences in hospitals and the patients they serve.  "There is no adjustment for socioeconomic factors and we know that readmission rates for poor patients are higher," says Akin Demehin, senior associate director for policy for the American Hospital Association.  [...] a typical readmission rate for a heart attack patient is around 18 percent, but for a poor patient it rises to 20 to 25 percent, he says.  On a recent afternoon, sitting at her dining room table, she breaks into a big grin when a pharmacist calls.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
